abstract.p: The aim of the research project was to investigate and maximize the thermal conductivity of polymer compounds with low filler content (<30 vol%). The study focused on the effect of the matrix material, the filler type, the processing method and the interaction of the fillers. It was concluded that compression-moulded samples have higher thermal conductivity than injection-moulded samples due to the segregation effect and the orientation of the anisotropic fillers. Conductivity can be improved by adding fillers with higher thermal conductivity, and also by combining, or hybridizing the fillers. A synergetic behaviour between hexagonal boron-nitride and talc which improved thermal conductivity was found.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymers are popular engineering materials because of their relatively low density, low cost, good chemical resistance, low thermal conductivity and ease of processability compared to other materials. The typical thermal conductivity values of polymers are between 0.1 and 0.5 W/mK. Polymers normally have good insulating properties, but thermally conductive polymer composites get more and more attention in the industry. The drive to reduce the size of electronic components has resulted in the generation of a larger amount of heat in the same area or volume. This has led researchers to develop new polymer composite materials that can dissipate more heat.1–4

Traditionally, the thermal conduction of insulating polymers is enhanced by adding highly conductive fillers such as carbon-based, metallic or ceramic particles. The thermal conductivity coefficient of these polymer composites is determined by several factors, such as filler concentration, the thermal conductivity of the fillers, their particle size and shape, the manufacturing process and filler-matrix interactions. These parameters are also important for modelling and predicting the thermal conductivity of compounds.2,5,6 To obtain composite materials with appropriate thermal conductivity, high filler content is usually required, although this will increase processing difficulties. Although viscosity is increased in this case, thermal conductivity is also increased significantly, resulting in more rapid cooling of the part thus reducing the polymer moulding cycle times. However, this increased cooling rate can also lead to problems with shrinkage and warpage.1–7

Measured thermal conductivity values are much lower than those estimated by the rule of mixtures approach. Poor dispersion and the so-called segregation effect are the primary factors responsible for this.8–10 Dispersion is most critical in the case of polymer composites including nanofillers.11 On the other hand, a large nanofiller volume fraction may cause problems, such as agglomeration, the increase of composite melt viscosity and the degradation of mechanical properties. Yang et al.12,13 concluded that a hybrid filler system with conductive networks is significant for the fabrication of next generation heat dissipation materials.

Thermally conductive polymers are widely investigated by many researchers, but few of them have carried out research into the effect of hybrid fillers. Teng et al.14 investigated the hybrid effect of multi-walled carbon nanotubes and boron-nitride (BN) flakes on the thermal conductivity of epoxy composite. They found that hybrid fillers provide a significant enhancement of thermal conductivity; 30 vol% BN and 1 vol% functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes resulted in a 740% increase in thermal conductivity of epoxy resin (1.9 W/mK). Yang and Gu13 enhanced the thermal conductivity of epoxy resin with functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes and silane-modified nano-sized silicon carbide as hybrid fillers. It was established that a hybrid filler system could provide a synergistic effect and also reduces costs, thus the thermal conductivity of epoxy nanocomposites with a hybrid filler system is higher than that of epoxy nanocomposites with any single filler system. Yang et al.12 proved the synergetic effect between the multi-graphene platelets and multi-walled carbon nanotubes in the mechanical properties and thermal conductivity of epoxy composites. The composite material containing 0.9 wt% graphene platelets and 0.1 wt% MWCNT showed a 47% increase in thermal conductivity, a 14.5% increase in tensile strength and a 22.6% increase in tensile modulus.

In our work, the aim was to analyze the effect of different parameters on the thermal conduction of conductive composites with a low filler content. The maximum filler content was 30 vol% so that it could be processed with injection moulding. Three different matrix materials and two different fillers (hexagonal BN and talc) were investigated. Samples were prepared with compression moulding and injection moulding to show the effect of shear-induced orientation and segregation on thermal conductivity. BN and talc were used as hybrid fillers in different mixing ratios. In this research, a positive hybrid effect was detected, which resulted in improved thermal conductivity.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: In this work, the thermoplastic matrix materials were H145 F polypropylene (PP) homopolymer (Tiszai Vegyi Kombinát Nyrt., Hungary; density is 0.9 g/cm3), K693 PP block copolymer (Tiszai Vegyi Kombinát Nyrt., Hungary; density is 0.92 g/cm3) and Schulamid 6 MV 13 polyamide 6 (A. Schulman Hungary Kft., Hungary; density is 1.13 g/cm3). The fillers were hexagonal BN grade A 01 powder (H.C. Starck GmbH, Germany) and talc (Mg3Si4O10(OH)2) (Novia Kft., Hungary). The average thermal conductivity of BN is about 60 W/mK, its density is 2.2 g/cm3 and its maximum particle size is about 5 µm. The average thermal conductivity coefficient of talc is about 10 W/mK, its density is 2.7 g/cm3 and its average particle size is about 25 µm. The surface of fillers was not modified.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p:
The proper amounts of matrix and filler materials were calculated with equations (1) and (2). (1)mf=mcϕm·ρmϕf·ρf+1 (2)mm=mc-mf where mc, mf and mm (g) are the weight of the composite, the filler and the matrix material, ϕf and ϕm (vol%) are the volume fraction of the filler and matrix material, and finally ρf and ρm (g/cm3) are the density of the filler and matrix material. The materials containing 0–30 vol% fillers were compounded with LabTech Scientific extruder and granulated with LabTech pelletizer. Then 80 × 80 × 2 mm-sized samples were injection moulded with Arburg Allrounder 370 S 700-290 injection moulding machine. The main injection moulding parameters are listed in Table 1. Table 1.

sec.title: Thermal conductivity measurements
sec.p: In physics, thermal conductivity (λ) is a material property that indicates the material’s ability to transfer heat from one location to another. In this research, thermal conductivity was measured using the transient hot-plate method. The aim of the process is to reach a steady-state condition, thus simplifying the measurement to a one-dimensional case where Fourier’s law (equation (3)) can be used.15,16 (3)q(x,t)=-λ·∇T(x,t) where q (W) is the transmitted heat flux, λ (W/(mK)) is the thermal conductivity and T (K) is the temperature.

In this research, a single-specimen hot-plate apparatus (Figure 1) was developed for measuring the thermal conductivity of the samples. In contrast to the conventional two-specimen apparatus, heat flows in a single direction between the hot plate and the cold plate through the specimen. Furthermore, in this arrangement, a cold plate, a hot plate and a specimen can be omitted, thus simplifying the apparatus. According to Fourier's law (equation (3)), thermal conductivity in the case of the one-specimen hot-plate method can be calculated using equation (4).17 (4)λ=PS·LT2-T1 where P (W) is the electrical power, S (m2) is the cross-section area and L (m) is the thickness of the specimen T1 (K) is the temperature of the cooled side and T2 (K) is the temperature of the heated side of the sample. Figure 1.
Heat conduction measurement system.

Figure 1 shows the main components of the measurement system. The main task is to maintain the temperature difference between the cold and the hot plate. The thermal conductivity of the copper plates is ∼380 W/mK, which is two orders of magnitude higher than that of the samples, thus their heat resistance does not generate a significant error. The cold plate of the apparatus was cooled by four 40 × 40 mm-sized Peltier cells, which facilitated keeping the temperature of the plate more precisely. The upper plate was heated by a heating wire, where the generated heat is equal to the electrical energy flowing through the wire (ignoring the losses). To provide uniform heating of the hot plate, the heating wire was meander-shaped. The heat resistance between the components was minimized with thermally conductive tapes (3 M 8805). The temperature was measured by 2 built-in NTC thermistors (Epcos B57045K) inside both the heated and the cooled plate. The resistance-temperature calibration for the NTC thermistors was performed with the Steinhart-Hart equation (equation (5)).18 (5)1T=A+Bln(R)+C(ln(R))3 where R (Ω) is the resistance of the thermistors at given temperatures T (K) and A, B and C are the Steinhart-Hart constants. Table 2 contains the values of the Steinhart-Hart constants obtained by calibration. To minimize heat loss, the apparatus was thermally insulated with polystyrene foam, whose thermal conductivity is ∼0.04 W/mK. To decrease the thermal resistance between the samples and the hot-plate apparatus, ceramic powder-filled thermal interface silicone grease (T Silox Kft., Hungary) was applied. Finally, the accuracy of the apparatus was calibrated with known samples. Table 2.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: A number of parameters have a significant influence on the thermal conductivity coefficient of polymer compounds, including filler material, filler volume fraction, the thermal conductivity of the filler and the polymer material etc. These parameters should be further investigated to determine their exact effect on thermal conductivity.

sec.title: The effect of the matrix material on thermal conduction
sec.p:
In this paper, first the effect of the matrix material on thermal conductivity was investigated. Two different PPs and a polyamide 6 were filled with the same type of talc. As Figure 2 shows, the thermal conductivities of PPs are 0.25 W/mK and 0.32 W/mK, while the thermal conductivity of polyamide is 0.39 W/mK. The differences between the coefficients measured as a function of talc content remain nearly the same. Accordingly, compounding the different matrices with 30 vol% talc, the thermal conductivities are 0.59 W/mK using H145 F PP, 0.64 W/mK using K693 PP and 0.86 W/mK using a polyamide 6 matrix. Figure 2.
Thermal conductivity of different matrix materials as a function of talc content.

sec.title: The effect of fillers on thermal conductivity
sec.p:
Second, the effect of filler material and filler content on the thermal conductivity of the polymer matrix was investigated. The matrix material was H145 F PP and it was compounded with talc and BN. The filler content was varied between 0 and 30 vol%. Figure 3 shows the effect of the different fillers on the thermal conductivity of the compounds. As was expected, thermal conductivity increases as filler content increases. Pure PP has a thermal conductivity of 0.25 W/mK. The thermal conductivity of the compounds rises slowly at low filler volume fractions because the ceramic particles are dispersed evenly in the PP matrix and there is little interaction between them. There are significant differences between the thermal conductivities of the compounds at high filler loading. The thermal conductivity coefficient of the composites filled with BN rises rapidly but that of the samples filled with talc and titanium-dioxide rises slowly. With 30 vol% of filler, the thermal conductivity coefficient of the compound is 0.6 W/mK with talc and almost double that amount, 1.14 W/mK, with BN. The thermal conductivity of the compound containing 30 vol% BN is more than four times higher than that of pure PP. Figure 3.
Thermal conductivity of H145 F PP as a function of boron nitride and talc content.

sec.title: The effect of the moulding process on thermal conduction
sec.p:
When the thermal conductivity of injection-moulded and compression-moulded samples are compared, it can be seen that compression-moulded samples have higher thermal conductivity (Figure 4). There is also a difference in the thermal conduction of unfilled PP. While the injection moulded sample has a conductivity coefficient of 0.25 W/mK, the compression-moulded sample has a conductivity coefficient of 0.36 W/mK. It can be explained by the difference in crystallinity and molecular chain orientation. Adding fillers to the matrix, the difference increases as a function of the filler content. In this case, the shell-core effect has a significant influence on thermal conductivity – on the surface of the injection moulded samples there is an insulating polymer layer. This effect is caused by the segregation effect while the polymer fills the cavity. On the other hand, this difference can also be caused by the orientation of the fillers, as thermal conductivity of the particles has an anisotropic nature. The plate-like and fibrous particles show different thermal properties in different directions. In compression-moulded samples, the filler particles have random directions, while in the injection-moulded samples, the orientation is determined by the melt flow. In this way, injection-moulded parts have a lower thermal conductivity coefficient. Figure 4.
Effect of the moulding process on thermal conductivity of polypropylene/talc composite material as a function of filler content.

sec.title: The synergetic effect of talc and hexagonal BN
sec.p:
To show the hybrid effect between BN and talc, further measurements were performed. In this case, thermal conductivity was measured on three compression-moulded specimens. Table 3 contains the notation of the compounds and specimens. The specimens had a thermal interface material between them, which reduced thermal resistance (Figure 5). First the thermal conductivity of hybrid materials were determined (H1 and H2), using three specimens joined together in each measurement. Second, the thermal conductivity of materials with a single filler was determined (compounds A and B). Third, the conductivity of the specimens joined together (Figure 5) was determined. A system made up of specimens filled with a single filler was also tested, first with specimen arrangement AAB then with ABB. Total filler content was 30 vol% in each case and the BN and talc content was the same as in the case of the hybrid material, but only specimens with a single filler were used for the measurement of thermal conductivity. Figure 5.
Arrangements for thermal conductivity measurements (a and b are compounds with 30 vol% single filler; c is a compound with 30 vol% hybrid filler).

As Figure 6 shows, in the case of specimens containing a single filler, a linear relationship can be observed between the thermal conductivity of BN and talc. Thus, thermal conductivity can be easily calculated as a function of filler content. If talc and BN are hybridized, a higher thermal conductivity can be achieved and the relationship between the fillers becomes nonlinear. As it was mentioned, this positive synergetic effect can be explained with the different particle size of BN and talc. In the mixture, talc particles formed the main thermally conductive path in the compound, while the smaller BN particles established more contact between the larger particles to obtain higher thermal conductivity. Figure 6.
Comparison of the effect of single and hybrid BN/talc fillers on compression moulded samples (notation in Table 3).

Next, the thermal conductivity of the injection-moulded and the compression-moulded samples were compared to each other, showing the effect of the sample preparation methods on hybrid-filled composite materials. The same compound was used for both sample preparation methods, thus the filler content was the same. Before compression-moulding the samples, the granules were milled to avoid air traps during the process. The measurement results can be seen in Figure 7. At each measurement point, the thermal conductivity of the compression-moulded samples was about 60% higher than that of the injection-moulded ones. It was found that the skin-core effect has a great influence on thermal conductivity. The skin layer has lower filler content, thus it behaves as an isolating layer, which decreases heat transfer. Figure 7.
Comparison of the effect of moulding process on BN/talc hybrid filled H145 F PP.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, a comprehensive research project on thermally conductive composites containing ceramic fillers was presented. Five different factors were considered: the type of polymer matrix, the type of filler, its volume fraction, the moulding method and finally the interaction of the fillers. We have concluded that changing the matrix material causes no significant increase in conductivity, because the polymers have low thermal conductivity with a negligible difference between them. As there are major differences between the thermal conductivity of fillers, they have a remarkable effect on thermal conductivity. If filler content is increased, the deviation in the values increases as well. If H145 F PP is compounded with 30 vol% talc, the thermal conductivity coefficient of the composite is 0.6 W/mK, while with 30 vol% BN it is 1.14 W/mK. The difference is 0.55 W/mK, and if filler content is lowered, the difference decreases, too; at 20 vol% filler content it drops to 0.3 W/mK.

The hybrid effect between talc and BN was also studied. Using the same amount of fillers, it was noted that a hybrid composite containing both BN and talc as fillers has almost 10% higher thermal conductivity than a composite containing only BN or talc. At a certain filler content, if the ratio of the fillers is varied, the thermal conductivity coefficient shows a nonlinear behaviour. Finally, it was concluded that the moulding process also influences thermal conduction. Compression-moulded samples always show higher conductivity than injection-moulded samples because of the shell-core structure of injection-moulded samples. The difference between the shell and the core layer can be explained with the shear-induced difference between the orientations of the anisotropic filler particles, which can result in an insulating layer on the surface.
